content.text: Calculate the acceleration of the rocket
acceleration =   .........
On Fig. 1.1, draw the graph for the motion of the rocket in the first 8.0s
Use the graph to determine the height of the rocket at 8.0s
From time \(= 8.0s\) to time \(= 20.0s\), the rocket rises with increasing speed but with decreasing acceleration
From time \(= 20.0s\) to time \(= 25.0s\), the rocket has a constant speed of less than \(200 \text{m/s}\)
A rocket is launched vertically upwards from the ground. The rocket travels with uniform acceleration from rest. After 8.0s, the speed of the rocket is \(120 \text{m/s}\)
The mass of the athlete is \(71 \text{kg}\). Calculate the impulse applied to her as she slows down
impulse =   .........
Define impulse in terms of force and time
The athlete takes 1.2 s to slow down from a speed of \(10.0 \text{m/s}\) to a speed of \(4.0 \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the average resultant force applied to the athlete as she slows down
Calculate the force required to give a mass of \(71 \text{kg}\) an acceleration of \(6.4 \text{m/s}^2\)
Fig. 2.1 shows an athlete crossing the finishing line in a race. As she crosses the finishing line, her speed is \(10.0 \text{m/s}\). She slows down to a speed of \(4.0 \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the speed of the air
The kinetic energy of the air drives a generator. State the input power of the air passing through the turbine blades
input power =   .........

The mass of air passing through the circular area swept out by the turbine blades each second is \(7.5\mathrm{kg}\). The kinetic energy of the air that passes through this circular area each second is \(240\mathrm{J}\)
Calculate the output power of the generator
output power =   .........
Calculate the efficiency of the wind turbine
efficiency =   .........  %
The output current of the generator is 2.0A. The output potential difference (p.d.) of the generator is 11V
The density of air is \(1.3 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
Calculate the volume of air passing through the circular area swept out by the turbine blades each second
Fig. 3.1 shows a model of a wind turbine used to demonstrate the use of wind energy to generate electricity. The wind is blowing towards the model, as shown
Define the specific latent heat of fusion of a substance
the specific heat capacity of water
specific heat capacity =   .........
the mass of ice added to the water

Small pieces of ice at \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) are added to \(0.35\mathrm{kg}\) of water. The initial temperature of the water is \(24.5^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The temperature of the water decreases to \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The water loses \(35 000\mathrm{J}\) of thermal energy as it cools. All of the ice added to the water melts
The specific latent heat of fusion of ice is \(3.3 \times 10^{5} \text{J / kg}\)
Calculate:
Complete the sentences with words that describe the main process of thermal energy transfer in each case
A man goes for a walk on a cold day. He touches a metal gate, which removes thermal
energy from his hands by ............................ . He holds the sides of a cup containing a
hot drink. His hands gain thermal energy by .................................. . Some farm workers have
lit a fire. The man warms his hands by the side of the fire. His hands gain thermal energy by
Describe in terms of particles the transfer of thermal energy through the metal of the gate after transfer from the man's hands
Fig. 5.1 shows a car on a sunny day in a hot country
The object labelled A is placed inside the windscreen. It is used by the owner of the car to reduce the temperature rise of the air in the car
Ring the most suitable material for the outer surface of object A. Explain your choice
**dull black** **dull white** **shiny black** **shiny white**
explanation
On Fig. 6.1, draw three more crests to the right of point A
State the name of the wave process that occurs as the wave passes point A
Fig. 6.1 shows crests of a water wave moving from left to right in a harbour
On Fig. 6.2, draw an arrow to show the direction of movement of the wave after it has passed into the shallow water
State the name of the process that occurs as the wave passes into the shallow water
Complete Table 6.1 to state whether each of the properties of the wave increases, decreases or stays the same as the wave passes into the shallow water
Fig. 6.2 shows the crests of another wave moving from left to right in a different part of the harbour. This wave moves from deep water to shallow water
On Fig. 7.1, draw two rays to locate the position of the object
Draw the object and label it O
Ring all of the following distances that are equal to the focal length of the lens
AB AC CB 2AB
Fig. 7.1 shows a converging lens and the image I formed when an object is placed to the left of the lens. The principal focuses are labelled A and B and the centre of the lens is labelled C
On Fig. 7.2, draw the path of the red light within the triangular glass block
Fig. 7.3 shows green light passing through a rectangular glass block
Red light enters the rectangular glass block shown in Fig. 7.3 along the same path as the green light
On Fig. 7.3:
draw the path of the red light within the rectangular glass block
draw the path of the red light after leaving the rectangular glass block
Fig. 7.2 shows green light passing through a triangular glass block
Red light enters the triangular glass block shown in Fig. 7.2 along the same path as the green light
Calculate the reading on the ammeter
ammeter reading =   .........

Fig. 8.2 shows the circuit with a different connection to the resistance wire and an added resistor. The length XY of the whole resistance wire is \(2.0 \text{m}\). The contact is made at Q where the distance XQ is \(0.60 \text{m}\)
Calculate the resistance of the circuit
resistance =   .........
Fig. 8.1 shows a circuit
The lamp has a resistance of \(3.0 \Omega\). Line XY represents a uniform resistance wire of resistance \(6.0 \Omega\)
State the name of the logic gate with the symbol shown in Fig. 9.1
Fig. 9.1
State the name of the logic gate with the truth table shown in Table 9.1
Fig. 9.2 shows a digital circuit
Fig. 9.2
Complete the truth table in Table 9.2 for this circuit for all possible combinations of input
Fig. 10.1 is a simplified top view of a flat coil. There is an alternating current (a.c.) in the coil
Describe the magnetic effect of this alternating current
Fig. 10.2 shows a pan placed above the coil. The base of the pan is made of steel
State what quantity is induced in the base of the pan
The pan contains water
State and explain the effect of the quantity induced in part **(b)** on the temperature of the water in the pan
The isotope hydrogen-1 has a proton number of 1 and a nucleon number of 1
Two isotopes of helium are helium-3 and helium-4
Helium-3 has a proton number of 2 and a nucleon number of 3
Helium-4 has a nucleon number of 4
Complete Table 11.1 for neutral atoms of these isotopes of helium

table.html:
helium-3helium-4
number of neutrons
number of electrons
mass compared to a neutral atom of hydrogen-1

content.text: An experiment takes place in a laboratory shielded from all background radiation. A sample of radioactive material is wrapped in aluminium foil of thickness 0.1 mm. A detector of ionising radiation placed 1 cm from the foil records a reading
A piece of aluminium of thickness \(5\mathrm{mm}\) is placed between the detector and the foil. The detector reading drops to zero
State and explain any type of radiation passing through the aluminium foil
